items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Education Code 84040(b) requires that each governing board of each community college district provide an annual audit of all funds, books, and accounts of the district in accordance with regulations of the Board of Governors.  
	 
The attached engagement letters/contracts for independent audit services and income tax services for fiscal year 2015/16 are submitted to the Board for approval.  The engagements include audit services for the annual District audit, Measure C Bond Performance Audit, Measure C Bond Financial Audit, Foothill-De Anza Community Colleges Foundation audit, and the California History Center Foundation audit.  In addition, the engagement includes income tax return preparation services for the Foothill-De Anza Community Colleges Foundation and the California History Center Foundation.  The total fee for these services is $164,450.  This total fee is unchanged from the fee that was charged in fiscal year 2014/15 for these same services.
	 
Staff will prepare a Request for Proposals (RFP), in coordination with the Audit and Finance Committee, in the Fall of 2016, for audit services beginning in fiscal year 2016/17 through 2021/22. The selection of the finalist audit firm will be brought to the Board for approval at their regularly scheduled meeting, March 2017.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
Is backup provided?
 Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On December 2, 2015, the Foothill College Planning & Resource Council (PaRC) approved a new mission statement for the college as recommended by the ad hoc Mission Statement Review Committee.  The Educational Master Plan Steering Committee had recommended to PaRC an out-of-cycle mission statement review given the community discussions involved in the development of the new master plan.  The ad hoc committee met several times in the fall quarter and considered several criteria, including:
Previous Foothill College Mission Statements
ACCJC Eligibility Requirements and Standards
Intended student populations
Degree programs
Revised Master Plan Goals
Proposed Foothill College Mission Statement:
	 
Believing a well-educated population is essential to sustaining and enhancing a democratic society, Foothill College offers programs and services that empower students to achieve their goals as members of the workforce, as future students and as global citizens. We work to obtain equity in achievement of student outcomes for all California student populations, and are guided by our core values of honesty, integrity, trust, openness, transparency, forgiveness, and sustainability.
	 
Submitted by:
Kimberlee Messina, Foothill College Interim President
Additional contact names:
Kurt Hueg, Andrew LaManque
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Foothill administration recommends approval of the revised mission statement.

items.item_text_raw: 5. De Anza College Educational Master Plan

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In January 2015, Foothill College began the process of updating the Educational Master Plan (EMP). The current plan (2010-2020) was completed in 2009-2010 to serve as the primary planning document for the college, demonstrating how the institution’s activities and initiatives support the college mission statement. While this plan has been revised since the fall 2011 accreditation site visit, participatory governance discussions indicated that there was support to conduct a full update of the EMP in preparation for the upcoming accreditation self-study (2016-17) and site visit (Fall 2017). An update, rather than a revision of the document, was also deemed appropriate due to the significant changes that occurred with the college’s governance, planning and budget prioritization processes since the last site visit. As part of the continuous cycle of improvement, the college seeks to ensure that this EMP update reflects how the institution is accomplishing its mission; whether the mission directs institutional priorities in meeting the educational needs of students; whether evidence supports these discussions; and how efforts to change, make improvements and instill accountability occur through a data-driven process.
	 
To frame this EMP update effort, Foothill College is guided by its core values of honesty, integrity, trust, openness, transparency, forgiveness, and sustainability. These beliefs manifest in the process the college undertook to complete the updated document. As such, a grassroots effort was employed to determine what the institution should focus on over the next eight years. A mixed methodological approach was used to collect, review, disseminate and discuss data that would inform the EMP. Internal and external constituents were encouraged to participate, either by providing their perspective or reflecting on existing student data. Multiple modalities ensured many opportunities for inclusion and participation (face-to-face, online). While this effort required significant time and coordination, the EMP goals and objectives were identified and approved through participatory governance in less than one year (Planning and Resource Council, November 4, 2015). 
	 
During this update process, the EMP steering committee recommended that the college mission be revised to be in better alignment with the EMP goals and objectives. This effort was approved in fall 2015 by the college’s main shared governance body, and this process was finalized and concluded by early December 2015 (Planning and Resource Council, December 2, 2015).
	 
Foothill College Educational Master Plan Goals and Objectives 
	 
These goals are approached in a way that exemplifies Foothill College’s culture of innovation and problem solving, with emphasis on eliminating disproportionate impact among student groups:
	 
Create a culture of equity that promotes student success, particularly for underserved students.
Implement activities to improve achievement of student outcomes among those population groups experiencing disproportionate impact.
Reduce barriers and facilitate students’ ease of access across the District and region.
Enhance support for online quality and growth for (internet/web-based) instruction and student services.
Collaborate with K-12, adult education and four-year institutions in ways that serve students and society.
Partner with business and industry to prepare students for the workforce.
Strengthen a sense of community and commitment to the College’s mission; expand participation from all constituencies in shared governance.
Encourage student participation in leadership and activities outside the classroom (including service/work-based learning) that engages students with the College and the community.
Provide effective onboarding, support and professional development for all college employees.
Encourage employee participation in leadership and activities that engages them with the College and the community.
Promote consistent and clear communication in order to create a more informed, cohesive and engaged community.
Increase lifelong learning opportunities for our community.
Promote decision-making that respects the diverse needs of the entire college community.
Recognize and support a campus culture that values ongoing improvement and stewardship of resources.
Increase advocacy at the state level, increase grants and private donations to secure stable and sustainable funding, and manage college resources strategically.
Expand college practices and initiatives to support environmental stewardship.
Employ data-driven decision-making.
Submitted by:
Kimberlee Messina, Foothill College Interim President
Additional contact names:
Kurt Hueg, Andrew LaManque
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College administration recommends approval of the Educational Master Plan Update.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Foothill College Curriculum Committee approved the Program Proposal for a Bachelor of Science in Dental Hygiene on January 19, 2016.  The proposed program follows the guidelines included in the California Community College Chancellor’s Office “Baccalaureate Degree Pilot Program Handbook.”
	 
As outlined in the Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) Substantive Change request (approved by ACCJC on May 19, 2015), the new program will replace the existing Associates in Science program and will use existing faculty, learning, and student support resources.  Students will continue to take the same National Dental Hygiene Board examination.  The department will also offer an option to allow existing Dental Hygiene Associate Degree holders to complete bachelor level requirements.  
	 
The program is proposed to start in Fall 2016.  The Dental Hygiene Associates Degree will be phased out beginning in Summer 2017.
	 
Submitted by:
Kimberlee Messina, Foothill College President
Additional contact names:
Kurt Hueg, Andrew LaManque
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Campus Abroad Program was re-started in 2014 after a hiatus of approximately 10 years.  The first year, in London, we had 32 students and 2 faculty.  Last year, in Florence, we had 43 students.
	 
This year, we have received well over 100 inquiries already and more are coming in every day.  As our website states:
	 
"Barcelona is one of the most vibrant and cosmopolitan cities in the world, and the second largest city in Spain with a population of approximately 1.7 million. It is a renowned center of art, music, and architecture (including the amazing Basilica La Sagrada Familia, one of the instantly recognizable and iconic architectural triumphs in the world)."  http://www.foothill.edu/campusabroad/ 
	 
Why Study Abroad?
Understand and appreciate other cultures as well as your own. By immersing yourself in a different culture you can enrich your future, broaden your horizons, and come back home with new goals. 
Gain a global education. Studying abroad enables you to gain a global perspective as it provides valuable insights into how other peoples work and live.
Learn a Foreign Language. Language study abroad provides an unparalleled opportunity for attaining fluency in a foreign language.
Expand your career potential. You will gain a competitive edge that future employers will recognize in a society which is becoming increasingly international in scope.
Earn academic credit. Studying abroad means a rewarding experience filled with adventures, fun and memories - all while earning college credit.
Barcelona has a world class airport which makes it easy for our students to travel to other sites in Europe.  Rail service in Spain is fantastic and will make it easy for our students to visit Madrid, Seville, Valencia, Granada, Salamanca, etc.
	 
AIFS did a fantastic job with the program in London, and provided superlative support for our students, and we have heard nothing but great things about their study Center in the heart of Barcelona.
	 
Submitted by:
Foothill College Interim President Kimberlee Messina
Additional contact names:
Mark Anderson
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College administration recommends approval of the Campus Abroad 2016 Barcelona Proposal.

Background and Analysis:
	 
Student trustee Alexander Park was unable to attend the regular Board meeting of January 11, 2016, due to a family emergency.  As stated in Education Code ยง72024(d):
	 
A member may be paid for any meeting when absent if the board, by resolution duly adopted and included in its minutes, finds that, at the time of the meeting, he or she is performing services outside the meeting for the community college district, he or she was ill or on jury duty, or the absence was due to a hardship deemed acceptable by the board. The compensation shall be a charge against the funds of the district.
	 
Included for adoption by the Board is a resolution verifying the circumstances of student trustee Park's absence as required by Education Code Section 72024(d).

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Sound Fiscal Management Self-Assessment Checklist report is prepared each fiscal year by district Business Office staff as an additional step in the overall process of ensuring fiscal stability and continuous scrutiny of district business practices and operations.  Although completion of the report on an annual basis is recommended by the state chancellor's office, it is not a requirement.  Foothill-De Anza Community College District chooses to produce the report each year because it is viewed by staff as a valuable tool for our own internal fiscal assessment and provides a comprehensive narrative document that is presented to both the Audit and Finance committee and the Board of Trustees.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x622

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges awarded a competitive grant to a partnership of the Foothill-De Anza and Butte Glenn community college districts to launch Governor Jerry Brown’s groundbreaking Online Education Initiative (OEI) for the state of California.  The goal of the initiative is to increase the number of California students who obtain associate degrees and transfer to four-year institutions. Online counseling and advising is an important component of this initiative and is anticipated to improve student success rates.
	 
In accordance with the California Public Contract Code (PCC) Section 20651(a) through (d), only the governing board may authorize award of purchase orders that exceed the legally mandated bid threshold, and the board must award the orders to the lowest responsible bidder or reject all bids.  However, in lieu of the district conducting its own bid process, Public Contract Code (PCC) section 20652 provides that community college districts may utilize contracts that have been awarded by other public entities. 
	 
As a lead agency of the OEI grant, Foothill-De Anza and the OEI Steering Committee will guide the success of the program.  Representatives from Foothill-De Anza, the OEI Steering Committee, and educators throughout the state sought the expertise of the Foundation for California Community Colleges to develop an RFP to secure online counseling and advising services in support of the OEI initiative.
	 
The Foundation for California Community Colleges awarded RFP #15-004 which is a piggybackable contract for online counseling and advising services which will help improve student success rates in support of the OEI initiative. This award was the result of a competitive RFP process conducted in accordance with the California Public Contract Code.
	 
The estimated cost for these services is $700,000 for the next 3.5 years and will be funded by the OEI grant. 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Joe Moreau, Bonnie Peters, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, recommends the Board of Trustees make a finding that it is in the best interest of the District to issue purchase orders for online counseling and advising services in excess of the legally mandated bid threshold to Cranium Café, LLC pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 and the Foundation for California Community Colleges RFP 15-004 for the duration of the contract.
items.item_text: Authorize the use of Foundation for California Community Colleges contract #RFP 15-004 for Online Counseling and Advising Services for the OEI Program from Cranium Café, LLC (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 14. Authorize the use of Foundation for California Community Colleges contract #RFP 15-004 for Online Counseling and Advising Services for the OEI Program from Cranium Café, LLC (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges awarded a competitive grant to a partnership of the Foothill-De Anza and Butte Glenn community college districts to launch Governor Jerry Brown’s groundbreaking Online Education Initiative (OEI) for the state of California.  The goal of the initiative is to increase the number of California students who obtain associate degrees and transfer to four-year institutions. 
	 
The contract includes services for proctoring students during online assessments/exams through a Course Management System (CMS), including measures for verifying student identity during proctored sessions, reporting suspected or observed instances of violating the rules of an online assessment/exam, and providing recorded or other documented evidence of such acts directly to the course instructor. 
	 
In accordance with the California Public Contract Code (PCC) Section 20651(a) through (d), only the governing board may authorize award of purchase orders that exceed the legally mandated bid threshold, and the board must award the orders to the lowest responsible bidder or reject all bids.  However, in lieu of the district conducting its own bid process, Public Contract Code (PCC) section 20652 provides that community college districts may utilize contracts that have been awarded by other public entities. 
	 
As a lead agency of the OEI grant, Foothill-De Anza and the OEI Steering Committee will guide the success of the program.  Representatives from Foothill-De Anza, the OEI Steering Committee, and educators throughout the state sought the expertise of the Foundation for California Community Colleges to develop an RFP to secure online academic integrity technologies/services in support of the OEI initiative. 
	 
The Foundation for California Community Colleges awarded RFP #CB 15-005 which is a piggybackable contract for online academic integrity technologies/services will support instruction for the OEI initiative.  This award was the result of a competitive RFP process conducted in accordance with the California Public Contract Code.
	 
The estimated cost for these services is $1,400,000 for the next 3.5 years and will be funded by the OEI grant.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Joe Moreau, Jory Hadsell, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Bid #1698 for the purchase and installation of a new chiller, chilled water pumps, motors and controls for the chilled water-cooling system at the De Anza College Science Center buildings was previously awarded to Pullman Construction by the Board of Trustees in 2015. During the course of construction, it was discovered that the existing roof pad was not designed to structurally uphold the replacement chiller.  Therefore, District staff worked with Salas O’Brien to develop bid specifications and receive Division of State Architect (DSA) approval of the required repairs to accommodate a new 242-ton chiller.  Additionally, Additive Alternate #1 requires the contractor to complete the installation of the Owner-furnished chiller, pumps, etc. (the scope of work which was removed from Bid #1698 in Change Order #7). 
	 
This bid was legally advertised to contractors on December 15 and December 22, 2015 in the San Jose Post Record/Daily Journal. Several Builders Exchanges and Contractors also received notification that they could receive bid documents through the FHDA portal of the PlanetBids website which is available by selecting "Bid Opportunities" at purchasing.fhda.edu.  Bids were publicly opened and read on January 22, 2016 in the Purchasing Services office. Four (4) contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:
	 
BID RESULTS

$344,503
$535,569
 Integra Construction Services Inc.
$489,587
$182,933
$672,520
	 
	 
The apparent low bidder is Calstate Construction Inc.  Furthermore, Calstate confirmed that its bid price of $480,944 for the Base Bid Proposal Amount plus Additive Alternate #1 is true and accurate for the work as specified and it confirmed that all first tier subcontractors were listed in accordance with Public Contract Code requirements. Calstate has successfully performed several projects for the District and is currently working on the electronic lock project at De Anza College.
	 
The construction estimate for the repairs plus the alternate work is $650,000.  The bid price of $480,944 is well within the estimated value and will be paid for by a combination of State of California Physical Plant Block Grant (Scheduled Maintenance) and Proposition 39 funds. 
	 
	 
	 
	 
Submitted by:
					  Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey 
Additional contact names:
					  Jennifer Mahato, Tom Armstrong, Steve Kitchen, Gina Bailey

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District anticipates the purchase of exterior LED luminaries and lighting fixtures to replace existing and add to the exterior pathways at De Anza College. Because the cost of the lighting fixtures will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $87,800, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts awarded by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking” and is permissible to utilize for community colleges under Public Contract Code section 20652. 
	 
In 2015 the Foundation for California Community Colleges (FCCC) competitively bid Exterior LED Luminaries (RFP #15-001). The contract was awarded to two vendors, GonLED and Wesco Distribution, Inc.  The Foundation acted in the capacity of a California Community College District and infused language to allow for any of California’s community colleges to utilize the Agreement. FCCC Contract #CB15-012 with Wesco Distribution, Inc. is valid through June 4, 2016 (with an option to renew for one additional year) and is available to the District; it includes the luminary and lighting fixtures that are required by the District. 
	 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than the prices offered on the FCCC contract for the same goods and services. The FCCC contract established discounts for luminaries and lighting fixtures, inclusive of enhanced warranties up to a 10-year period, related services, training, shipping, and delivery based on a tiered quantity system. 
	 
An initial purchase is estimated at about $205,000 for De Anza College quoted at the best pricing available and at the highest discount tier. The purchase will be funded by remaining Measure E dollars and also from the De Anza College facilities and equipment capital outlay funds account.
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, DIrector of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Susan Cheu, Donna Jones Dulin, Tom Armstrong, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, recommends the Board of Trustees make a finding that it is in the best interest of the District to issue purchase orders for Exterior LED Luminaries (lighting fixtures) and related services in excess of the legally mandated bid threshold pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 and the Foundation for California Community Colleges Contract # CB15-012 throughout the duration of the contract, including time extensions.
items.item_text: Authorize the use of Foundation for California Community Colleges contract #CB15-012 to purchase Exterior LED Luminaries and related services from Wesco Distribution, Inc.
items.item_text_raw: 18. Authorize the use of Foundation for California Community Colleges contract #CB15-012 to purchase Exterior LED Luminaries and related services from Wesco Distribution, Inc.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In 2011, the Board of Trustees adopted a pre-qualification process for prospective bidders of public projects pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20651.5 and Public Contract Code section 20101 that allow Community College Districts to require licensed contractors to pre-qualify for the right to bid on public projects. The laws require that Community College Districts (1) use a standardized questionnaire for the pre-qualification process, (2) adopt a uniform system of rating bidders on objective criteria to determine qualification, and (3) create an appeal system by which a contractor that has been found to be unqualified will receive a due process hearing if it chooses to dispute the District’s finding. 
	 
Members of the District’s construction management team have concluded that direct contractors on certain public projects should be pre-qualified to (a) ensure the financial stability of the contractors, and to (b) promote safety, quality, timeliness, and cost effectiveness in the construction of the projects. The construction management team has determined that the contractor prequalification process will be of value for the New District Offices project and also the Flint Garage project.  It may also be applied on other projects in the future.
	 
A draft of the model pre-qualification documents are attached; the content can also be incorporated into a public works bid. The previous documents have been revised to incorporate a contractor interview component and modify the weighted criteria of the evaluations to place more emphasis on contractor experience. Before concluding each pre-qualification process, the Purchasing Department will report the results to the Board of Trustees. At that time, the Board can choose to either:
	 
          1.     Accept the list of Direct Contractors who met all of the pre-qualification requirements as the only contractors who are “pre-qualified” to bid on the project, OR 
          2.     Cancel the pre-qualification procedure for Direct Contractors for that particular project(s).
	 
For each project, the pre-qualification of contractors shall be valid for one year if accepted by the Board of Trustees.
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen, Tom Armstrong, Art Heinrich, Roseanne Sciacchitano, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
  Yes
items.item_recommendation: Adopt the updated pre-qualification process for prospective bidders of public projects in accordance with Public Contract Code section 20651.5 and Public Contract Code section 20101.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The chiller unit that cools the D140 Annex building and the D120 ETS building is outdated and not functioning properly.  Replacement of the chiller was not included in the original scope of work for the Building D120 renovation. This project would require the contractor to install a new Owner-Furnished chiller, including all related chilled water pumps, electrical, and piping work.  The District purchased the chiller in efforts to expedite the completion of the work prior to the Summer months.  McCracken & Woodman prepared the design and bid specifications for the work.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on November 6 and November 13, 2015 in the San Jose Post Record/Daily Journal. Several Builders Exchanges and Contractors also received notification that they could receive bid documents through the FHDA portal of the PlanetBids website which is available by selecting "Bid Opportunities" at purchasing.fhda.edu.   Bids were publicly opened and read on January 14, 2016 in the Purchasing Services office. Five (5) contractors submitted bids however two bidders did not includes costs for the mechanical controls scope of work, which is a significant portion of the project.  Additionally, bids received were excessively higher than expected. 
	 
Due to the high cost of the project it is recommended that the District not move forward with the award of this bid.   District staff will work with McCracken & Woodman to revise the scope of work and rebid the project in an effort to reduce costs.
	 
According to Public Contract Code, Section 20651(b): “The governing board shall let any contract for a public project, as defined in subdivision (c) of Section 22002, involving an expenditure of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) or more to the lowest responsible bidder who shall give security as the board requires, or else reject all bids.”
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen, Art Heinrich, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: In accordance with PCC 20651(b), reject all bids for Bid Document 1741-405 – D120/D140 Chiller Replacement at Foothill College.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On December 10, 2012, the Board authorized award of a Preconstruction Services Agreement to Kitchell CEM, Inc. (Kitchell) based upon the recommendation of the contractor Selection Committee. The Preconstruction Services Agreement required Kitchell to prequalify subcontractors, obtain competitive bids from subcontractors, develop a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) to construct the project, and develop a Preliminary Construction Schedule.  On April 7, 2014 the Board of Trustees approved execution of the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease for the Project, which included a GMP for only the 3600 Swing Space Build Out Phase of the project. Kitchell has completed that phase of work.  On January 12, 2015 the Board of Trustees approved execution of Amendment Number 1 to the Facilities Lease for the Project, which included a GMP for only the Building 3500 Renovation Phase of the project. Kitchell completed  that phase of the work on  January 4, 2016.
	 
This Amendment modifies the Facilities Lease to include a GMP for a Building 3600 Renovation Phase of the Project in the amount of $2,789,874. This phase includes the remodel of existing media center building 3600.  Improvements include: mechanical system upgrades, roof replacement, and new interior finishes.
	 
This is the final Facilities Lease Amendment.  The construction budget for all Project phases is $13,800,000. The Library & ISC project is funded by Measure C.
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services x6166
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen, x6150, Art Heinrich x 6295, Gina Bailey x6165
Is backup provided?
  Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On January 12, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved an agreement between the District and the City of Sunnyvale that included a requirement for the District to maintain the portion of Innovation Way that lies within the District’s Education Center property.  With the assistance of the U.S. Department of Education, District staff re-negotiated the terms of that agreement such that the City of Sunnyvale will be responsible for future maintenance of Innovation Way at the Education Center.   
	 
A public access easement deed related to the maintenance agreement was approved by the Board at the same January 12, 2015 meeting.   The revised document has been changed slightly to coordinate its provisions with the maintenance agreement.
	 
Both of these documents will supersede those approved by the Board on January 12, 2015.
	 
Submitted by:
  Steve Kitchen, Executive Director of Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
  Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management for Foothill and District
Is backup provided?
  Yes
